name: Edward Norton
religion: Norton was raised an Episcopalian and an Anglican but identifies his childhood more with Judaism. He now practices no religion.
politicalViews: Norton is a Democrat and a liberal, supporting a variety of environmental causes and supporting various Democratic candidates.
author: Tom Kershaw

content.text: Edward Norton was born just outside of Baltimore, Maryland, the son of an environmental lawyer working in Asia and an English teacher.

content.sourceTitle: Ed takes a leap of faith
content.text: He was raised Anglican and Episcopalian but doesn't currently subscribe to any faith or denomination.
When it comes to the religious upbringing of his childhood, Norton identifies more with Judaism than anything else. He said:
I grew up an honorary Jew. If you go to more than ten barmitzvahs you get an honorary Jew certificate. I went to at least ten in one year. I was drunk on Manischevitz half of 1987!

There is a depth and humility to Norton that implies some sort of spirituality, but the notoriously reclusive actor doesn't much talk about these kinds of things. His attitude is that of a man not comfortable with fame and notoriety, a sort of Buddhist Zen. He once said:
If I ever have to stop taking the subway, I'm going to have a heart attack.
He just wants to be a normal guy.

content.sourceTitle: Edward Norton Discusses His HBO Obama Documentary On Countdown
content.text: Norton's political contributions point to someone who has gone to great lengths to formulate his views. First of all, he's a Democrat who even made a documentary film about the election of Barack Obama.

content.sourceTitle: As Spitzer's Popularity Fell, Donors Rallied to His Side
content.text: He was a big supporter of Democratic former New York governor Elliot Spitzer, donating thousands of dollars and rallying other stars to do so when it looked like his 2008 re-election campaign was losing steam.

Norton hated George W. Bush (like so many others), and even told a crowd at Cuyahoga Community College in Cleveland to please vote him out in 2004, basically calling the president stupid and ignorant and asking the crowd:

content.sourceTitle: Actor urges audience to vote Bush out
content.text: Do tax breaks for movie stars make any sense to you?
And it was well into the Bush years when Norton confessed:
I almost forgot what it's like to be proud of my government.

content.sourceTitle: An interview with actor and solar advocate Edward Norton
content.text: Norton is also an environmental activist. He has helped provide solar power to low-income families, which is cool, even if he did it by teaming up with oil giant BP.
He also addressed Congress, imploring them to take global warming seriously, saying:

content.sourceTitle: Ed Norton calls on Congress to fight global warming
content.text: I have very little doubt that the legacy of my generation is going to hinge on how we respond to these revelations that we're not living sustainably and that we are altering the environment.
